awd_titl_txt: Predicting the Nature of the Protein Corona: From Fundamental Modeling to Phenomenological Descriptors
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

#1236053
Hall, Carol K.

Excitement about the potential of nanotechnology to revolutionize the fields of electronics, materials, medicine, and energy is tempered by concerns about the impact of engineered nanomaterials on the environment and on human health. The small sizes that make nanomaterials so attractive for the creation of new molecular-scale engineering devices render them highly susceptible to adsorption by the human body through inhalation, ingestion and skin penetration. Previous studies suggest that toxicity is related to the physicochemical properties of nanoparticles such as size, shape, surface area, charge, agglomeration status, and hydrophobicity but no general trends have been established. Our research is based on the current thinking that a key step in the body's response to nanoparticle intrusion is the formation of the protein corona, an envelope surrounding the nanoparticle containing proteins adsorbed from the biological fluid following initial exposure. The long term goal of the proposed research is to develop a correlation tool capable of predicting the nature and composition of the protein corona on engineered nanomaterials.  This research is intended to be the first step in the development of risk assessment models for nanoparticles. Subsequent steps will be done with collaborators who plan to use the correlation to help predict the in vivo disposition (ADME) of nanomaterials, develop physiologically- based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) models and ultimately create risk assessment model. 

Intellectual Merit: The objectives are: (1) to predict which proteins in biological fluids adhere to specific engineered nanomaterials, (2) to provide a set of descriptors that characterize the composition and physico-chemical properties of the corona of a given engineered nanomaterial, and (3) to use these tools to rank order the affinities of proteins for specific nanoparticles. Multiscale modeling will be used to determine geometric and energetic parameters for a new intermediate-resolution model, "PRIME/NP" for protein/nanoparticle systems. Energy calculations based on PRIME/NP will be used to predict nanoparticle/protein affinities, and discontinuous molecular dynamics (DMD) simulations will be used to model competitive adsorption of proteins on nanoparticles.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research could impact research in the area of biomaterials where the biocompatibility of medical implants is an issue. In addition to training a (female)  Ph.D  student, research and education will be fostered by: (1) using  nanoparticle-protein corona formation, its relation to the potential toxicity of engineered nanomaterials, and the response to this issue by government and society as the basis for examples developed for the PI's undergraduate chemical engineering thermodynamics course, (2) creating a power-point presentation describing the basics of nanotechnology and  measurement of  toxicity for  dissemination via the web, and (3) making a video presentation targeted for general audiences that shows how molecular-level computer simulation can be used to understand nanoparticle toxicity  The PI will continue her considerable but informal activities to broaden the opportunities for women and will introduce a brown bag lunch series for women graduate students and postdocs in her department at NCSU.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview: A multiscale modeling investigation of protein-nanoparticle interactions was conducted with the aim of better understanding the formation of a corona of proteins around nanoparticles immersed in a biological fluid. Nanoparticles (NPs) can be found in microelectronics, textiles, cosmetics, coatings, and thousands of other commercial and industrial products.  Since they are small enough to enter and traverse the body, concern has arisen about the biological response to NPs and any potential toxic effects. A key determinant of the body’s response to NPs is the protein corona, the layer of proteins that forms around a NP once it enters a biological environment. As biological systems bind with and respond to the proteins in the corona, they can stimulate an immune response to, or cellular uptake of, the nanoparticle-corona complex.

Intellectual Merit

(1) Selective adsorption of natural amino acids on heterogeneous gold nanoparticles. The 20 natural amino acids possess various hydrophobicities, charges, and sizes. Gold nanoparticles also come in many sizes and have heterogeneous surfaces that are composed of regions with different types of facets. In one study, molecular–level simulations were used to identify the binding preferences (selectivities) of all 20 amino acids for gold nanoparticles with a range of diameters. In another study, well-tempered metadynamics simulations were used to identify the specific facets (111), (110) and (100) that glycine molecules (a proxy for the protein backbone) adsorb to, and how this changes as the nanoparticle diameter changes (Figures 1, 2 and 3). This research deepens our understanding of the adsorption of amino acids on nanoparticles, which helps in rational design of peptides that adsorb on nanoparticles. 

(2) Development of coarse-grained (CG) models that can describe protein-protein and protein-nanoparticle interactions. Simulation of the adsorption of proteins on nanoparticles necessitates the use of coarse-grained, as opposed to atomistic models, due to the large sizes of proteins and nanoparticles. A two-bead-per-residue model for proteins was developed. The geometric and energetic parameters for these models were obtained by calculating potentials of mean force (PMFs) between amino acids and their sidechains and gold nanoparticles via atomistic simulations. This model enables us to investigate protein adsorption on nanoparticles at  large length- and time-scales.

(3) Development of models that can describe protein adsorption on nanoparticles. The corona of proteins around a nanoparticle is formed through an adsorption process. The performance of seven well-known theoretical adsorption models, which describe adsorption on flat surfaces, was tested to see how well it accounts for the adsorption of two proteins, Trp-cage and WW domain, on a 10.0 nm nanoparticle. The results show that four adsorption models (Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, and Kiselev) do a reasonable but not outstanding job of describing the adsorption of proteins on the nanoparticle. This research suggests better ways to develop theoretical expressions for the adsorption of specific proteins on nanoparticles of arbitrary size.

(4) Allosteric effects of gold nanoparticles on the properties of human serum albumin protein. The influence of nanoparticles on protein properties plays an important role in biological and medical applications of nanoparticles. We showed that a gold nanoparticle can influence the flexibility and secondary structure of residues on an adsorbed protein, human serum albumin (HSA) through the allosteric effect. (See Figure 4.) This effect allows a nanoparticle to change a protein’s activity even if it binds to a region distant from the active site. Our results provide new and unexpected insights into the influence of nanoparticles on proteins. 

Broad Impact

(1) This project  trained 3 graduate students (1 female) and 1 postdoctoral associate .

(2) This research deepens our understanding of interfacial phenomena in complex nano-bio systems, as are used in nanotechnology applications. Peptides and proteins have been used to aid the manufacturing of nanoparticles. Our results may point the way to better manufacturing strategies. 

(4) The results of this project have been published as six papers in scientific  journals and presented multiple times at international and national conferences. Another publication is under review. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2017
Modified by: Carol K Hall
